messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 49 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Towards Real Smart Apps: Investigating Human-AI Interaction Patterns in Mobile On-Device AI Apps

Paper Abstract: Abstract. With the emergence of deep learning techniques, smartphone apps are now embedded on-device AI features for enabling advanced tasks like speech translation, to attract users and increase market competitiveness. A good interaction design is important to make an AI feature usable and understandable. However, AI features have their unique challenges like sensitiveness to the input, dynamic behaviours and output uncertainty. Existing guidelines and tools either do not cover AI features or consider mobile apps which are confirmed by our informal interview with professional designers. To address these issues, we conducted the first empirical study to explore user-AI-interaction in mobile apps. We aim to understand the status of on-device AI usage by investigating 176 AI apps from 62,822 apps. We identified 255 AI features and summarized 759 implementations into three primary interaction pattern types. We further implemented our findings into a multi-faceted search-enabled gallery. The results of the user study demonstrate the usefulness of our findings.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 49 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 49"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Collect, decompile, extract, stats, and diff: Mining design pattern changes in Android apps",
        "Guidelines for human-AI interaction",
        "Github. Interaction design gallery",
        "Interaction design gallery",
        "A meta-analytical review of empirical mobile usability studies",
        "Understanding Real-world Threats to Deep Learning Models in Android Apps",
        "Share of global smartphone shipments by operating system from 2014 to 2023",
        "Bert: Pre-training of deep bidirectional transformers for language understanding",
        "A survey of on-device machine learning: An algorithms and learning theory perspective",
        "UX design innovation: Challenges for working with machine learning as a design material",
        "Why people hate your app: Making sense of user feedback in a mobile app store",
        "Guidelines for handheld mobile device interface design",
        "Machine learning patterns",
        "Google - People + AI Research (PAIR)",
        "Machine learning for mobile developers",
        "Material Design",
        "TensorFlow Hub",
        "Conformer: Convolution-augmented transformer for speech recognition",
        "Intelligence on tap: artificial intelligence as a new design material",
        "Mobilenets: Efficient convolutional neural networks for mobile vision applications",
        "Smart app attack: hacking deep learning models in android apps",
        "Robustness of on-device models: Adversarial attack to deep learning models on android apps",
        "SqueezeNet: AlexNet-level accuracy with 50x fewer parameters and¡ 0.5 MB model size",
        "Core ML - Machine Learning",
        "Designing for iOS",
        "Human Interface Guidelines - Machine Learning",
        "Mining Visual Evolution in 21 Years of Web Design",
        "Colors–Messengers of Concepts: Visual Design Mining for Learning Color Semantics",
        "Preventing User Errors: Avoiding Unconscious Slips",
        "Deep learning",
        "Questioning the AI: informing design practices for explainable AI user experiences",
        "Question-Driven Design Process for Explainable AI User Experiences",
        "Object recognition from local scale-invariant features",
        "A survey of app store analysis for software engineering",
        "Computation of interface aesthetics",
        "Faster r-cnn: Towards real-time object detection with region proposal networks",
        "User Control and Freedom (Usability Heuristic)",
        "The influence of prototype fidelity and aesthetics of design in usability tests: Effects on user behaviour, subjective evaluation and emotion",
        "Human-centered artificial intelligence: Reliable, safe & trustworthy",
        "Biggest app stores in the world 2022 — Statista",
        "Mind your weight (s): A large-scale study on insufficient machine learning model protection in mobile apps",
        "Human-AI interaction: intermittent, continuous, and proactive",
        "A first look at deep learning apps on smartphones",
        "Transitioning to human interaction with AI systems: New challenges and opportunities for HCI professionals to enable human-centered AI",
        "The role of design in creating machine-learning-enhanced user experience",
        "Profiling Artificial Intelligence as a Material for User Experience Design",
        "Mapping machine learning advances from hci research to reveal starting places for design innovation",
        "Investigating how experienced UX designers effectively work with machine learning",
        "Re-examining whether, why, and how human-AI interaction is uniquely difficult to design"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 49 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Towards Real Smart Apps: Investigating Human-AI Interaction Patterns in Mobile On-Device AI Apps, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
